Graphical abstract Catalytic destruction of nitrogen-containing volatile organic compounds (NVOCs) is rarely reported although they can make great harm to the environment and public health. In the present work, a series of short rod-like micro-mesoporous composite SBA-15 materials (SBA-15-r) with developed porosity and enhanced mass transfer performance were rationally designed and synthesized, and highly dispersed and thermally stable Pd nanoparticles were successfully introduced into the mesopore channels of SBA-15-r via an extraordinary incipient wetness impregnation with the assistance of furfuryl alcohol and trimethylbenzene. The correlation between catalyst property and catalytic performance in n-butylamine destruction was elucidated. 29Si MAS NMR and FT-IR results show that phosphorus is incorporated into the skeleton of SBA-15-r through a POSi connection, altering the structural property of support. All Pd/SBA-15-r materials are highly active and stable catalysts with n-butylamine totally converted at 280 °C. Amongst, Pd/S-5 possesses the best n-butylamine oxidation activity and lowest NOx formation rate ascribable to the largest surface area and highest porosity which can promote the dispersion of Pd active sites and accelerate the oxidation process and product diffusion, inhibiting the formation of reaction byproducts. Moreover, the structural micropores over Pd/SBA-15-r catalysts play an important positive role in NOx formation control. The n-butylamine destruction mechanism were further discussed according to the results of gas chromatography and in situ DRIFTS. We believe that the present work provides new insights into the design and application of high-efficient catalysts based on hierarchical materials in NVOC elimination. Keywords N-butylamine Catalytic combustion Micro-mesoporous SBA-15 Highly dispersed Pd NOx byproduct control 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are main precursors of ozone and photochemical smog, which can make serious damage to the environment and human health [1,2]. Nitrogen-containing VOCs (NVOCs) such as amines, amides, nitro-compounds, and nitrile are one type of representative VOCs mainly emitted from industrial processes [3]. N-butylamine is widely used in pharmaceutical industrial and production of pesticide, causing great irritation to our eye, skin, and respiratory system. Nowadays, various methods have been developed for VOC removal such as adsorption, thermal combustion, photocatalytic decomposition, and catalytic combustion [4]. Amongst, the catalytic combustion is regarded as the most efficient and economical approach for the removal of VOCs with low concentrations [5]. Different from combustion of other kinds of VOCs, the yield of byproduct NOx should be specially concerned and controlled in catalytic combustion of NVOCs to avoid the secondary pollution [2,6,7]. However, the catalytic combustion of NVOCs is rarely studied at present. Noble metals are often used in VOC catalytic combustion due to their superior low-temperature activity. Amongst, platinum and palladium have been the most studied [8]. Compared with Pt, Pd is cheaper and has better resistance to thermal sintering and toxic compounds [9]. As such, Pd-based material is a promising catalyst for VOC combustion as the cost and stability are two of the most crucial factors determining the potential practical applications of a catalyst. The Pd particle size, active phase dispersion, preparation method, and palladium precursor type can influence the activity of Pd-based catalysts [1,10–12]. It is generally accepted that the support nature plays an important role in the improvement of catalytic oxidation efficiency. In general, material with high surface area, ordered pore channel, and developed porosity should be a desired support candidate. High surface area can enhance the dispersion of noble metal and increase the amount of active sites, and abundant ordered pores can accelerate reactant diffusion, enhance active site accessibility, and reduce the retention time of reaction products in catalyst [13]. Mesostructured SBA-15 has been widely used as catalyst support because of its high surface area, ordered pore structure, narrow pore size distribution, excellent hydrothermal stability, and potential ability to inhibit active particles growth and aggregation in its pores [14,15], appearing to be one of the best supports for Pd-loaded catalysts. However, conventional fiber-like SBA-15 possesses a 2D mesoporous structure with long and curved pore channels (even more than 100 μm) and densely packed secondary morphology, greatly limited the diffusion of large molecules within their pore channels and suppressed the mass transfer in catalytic reactions [16]. As such, modified SBA-15 with shorter pore channles in the form of films, spheres, rods, or platelets has been developed through the addition of salts/cosurfactants into the precursor solution or change preparation conditions [16–19]. For instance, Yu et al. [19] synthesized the rod-like SBA-15 with pore channel length of 1–2 μm by adding KCl into the synthesis system. Significantly, there exists residual micropores in the inorganic walls of the mesoporous structure, forming a 3D connected pore network which could promote mass transfer and reaction efficiency. The synthesis of SBA-15 with 3D micro-mesoporous composite structure has attracted increasing interests in recent years. Zhong et al. [20] prepared micro-mesoporous composite SBA-15 with various contents of residual micropores. Colilla et al. [21] adjusted the micropore volume in SBA-15 by adding different amounts of phosphoric acid into the precursor mixture. Zhu et al. [22] enhanced the content of micropore in SBA-15 by introducing poly vinyl alcohol (PVA) to the synthesis mixture and proved that the material with high micropore volume had better catalytic efficiency. Previous work suggested that noble metal confined catalysts possess high catalytic activity and stability as the pore channels of supports have the potential ability to inhibit active particles growth and aggregation during reactions. Various strategies were developed for incorporating metal nanoparticles into mesoporous silica, such as chemical vapor deposition, wet impregnation, and ion exchange [23–26]. However, the aforementioned approaches could not ensure the encapsulation of Pd nanoparticles inside the mesoporous channels, and hence large metal aggregates would form on the external surface of supports during thermal treatments or reactions. Noteworthily, researchers suggested that post grafting approach can control the location and size of metal nanoparticles [27]. However, the grafting method is relatively complicated and requires many expensive coupling agents. As a consequence, the exploring and developing a simple and efficient protocol for the preparation of noble metal confined catalysts is of great significance. In this work, a series of short rod-like micro-mesoporous composite SBA-15 supports with adjustable microporosity were synthesized in order to facilitate the diffusion of reactants and products. Moreover, we adopt a novel and economical incipient wetness impregnation approach, which allows the preparation of highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles within silica mesopores using Pd(acac)2 as Pd source and furfuryl alchohol (FA) and trimethylbezene (TMB) as co-solvent. It is regarded as that this is an universal protocol for the preparation of silica-confined metal catalysts. The aim of this research is to comprehensively investigate the catalytic properties (activity, selectivity, and stability) and mechanism of these novel Pd-confined catalysts in n-butylamine (a typical NVOCs) destruction, and emphatically illuminate the relationship between the material phsicochemical properties and catalytic performance. The application of synthesized micro-mesoporous composite materials in other regions such as catalysis, separation, and adsorption can be reasonably anticipated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of short rod-like SBA-15 support Typically, 3.2 g P123 (EO20PO70EO20) and 5.9 g KCl were dispersed in a solution contained 140 g of deionized water, 13.5 g HCl (36.5%), and a certain amount of H3PO4 (85%) under stirring at 38 °C. When the P123 and KCl were completely dissolved, 9.0 mL tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added dropwise. The mixture was reacted under a static condition at 38 °C for 24 h and then aged in a sealed Teflon container at 100 °C for 24 h. The solid was filtered and washed with deionized water thoroughly and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Template was removed by a two-step calcination, that is, heating at 350 °C for 3 h and then at 550 °C for 4 h (heating rate of 5 °C/min). According to the mole ratio of H3PO4/HCl = 0, 1/3, 1/2, 1/1, 2/1, 3/1, the SBA-15-r supports were labeled as S-1, S-2, S-3, S-4, S-5, and S-6, respectively. 2.1.2 Synthesis of Pd-confined catalysts A certain amount of Pd(acac)2 was dispersed in a mixed solution of furfuryl alcohol (FA) and trimethylbenzene (TMB). The volume ratio of FA: TMB is 2. Above mixture was used to infiltrate SBA-15 via an incipient wetness impregnation. Then, the sample was sequently heated at 60 and 80 °C (each for 12 h) for polymerization of FA. After drying at 60 °C for 12 h under vacuum, the powder was calcined at 550 °C for 6 h in N2 for carbonization of FA, then at 550 °C for 6 h in air to remove the carbon to obtain the Pd-confined catalyst. The sample was reduced in a pure H2 stream for 2 h at 480 °C. The obtained samples were labeled as Pd/S-1, Pd/S-2, Pd/S-3, Pd/S-4, Pd/S-5, and Pd/S-6. The theoretical Pd loading of these catalysts is 0.3 wt.%. 2.2 Material characterizations X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a powder diffractometer (PANalytical, Netherlands) equipped with Cu-Ka radiation in the 2θ range of 0.8–8° (scanning rate of 0.5°/min) and 10–80° (scanning rate of 4°/min), respectively. The tube voltage was 45 kV and the current was 40 mA. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured on a Builder SSA-6000 apparatus at liquid N2 temperature. The samples were pretreated at 300 °C under vacuum for 3 h. The specific surface area of the samples were calculated from the adsorption isotherm (P/P 0 = 0.05–0.30) by the Brunauere-Emmette-Telle (BET) method. The mesopore size distribution was got by the Barrette-Joynere-Halenda (BJH) method and the micropore size distribution was got by the Horvathe-Kawazoe (HK) method. Morphology of the samples were observed on a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, JEOL-7800F) operating at an acceleration voltage of 15 kV and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30, USA) operating at an acceleration voltage of 300 kV. Fourier transform spectroscopy (FT-IR) adsorption spectra of samples were recorded in a Tensor 37 (Bruker, Germany) FT-IR spectrometer in 4000–400 cm−1. 29Si MAS NMR was performed on a Bruke AVANCE Ⅲ 400WB. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were collected on a AXIS ULtrabld instrument (Kratos, UK) operated at 250 W using Mg-Kɑ radiation at 1253.6 eV. Binding energies (BE) were calibrated relative to the C 1s peak (284.8 eV). The actual Pd content over samples were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using a PerkinElmer OPTIMA 7000 DV. The temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were carried out on a PCA-1200 (Builder, China) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Typically, 75 mg samples were pretreated at 300 °C for 2 h in a flow of argon (40 mL/min). Then, the samples were reduced from room temperature to 400 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of 5% H2/Ar (50 mL/min). The hydrogen in the effluent was continuously monitored by the TCD. The Pd dispersion was determined by CO pulse chemisorption. Firstly, 75 mg catalyst was dehydrated at 300 °C for 1 h in a flow of argon (30 mL/min). Then, the catalyst was pretreated at 400 °C for 1 h in a flow of 5% H2/Ar (40 mL/min). After cooling down to room temperature (in a N2 stream), the sample was further exposed to N2 for 30 min. Finally, CO was pulsed every 2 min until the peak area unchanged. The dispersion of Pd was calculated using the following equation: (1) D ( % ) = V × M Pd W × C × 22414 × 100 where V is adsorption volume of CO (mL), M Pd is the molecular weight of palladium (g/mol), W is the weight of catalyst used (g), and C is the Pd content determined by ICP-OES (wt.%). In situ DRIFTS was performed on a Bruker Tensor 37 infrared spectrometer, equipped with a MCT detector which was cooled by liquid nitrogen. A small quality of catalyst was set into a small crucible and subsequently placed into the Harrick cell fitted with KBr windows. The sample was pretreated at 500 °C for 1 h in a N2 flow (60 mL/min). Then, a flow of mixed gas (20 vol.% O2/80 vol.% Ar) containing 1000 ppm n-butylamine was passed through the sample. All spectra were collected with a resolution of 4 cm−1 with 100 scans and recorded at each temperature point. 2.3 Catalytic performance N-butylamine catalytic combustion was carried out in a continuous flow fixed-bed steel reactor (I.D. = 10 mm) at atmospheric pressure. In each test, 1.0 mL (around 0.3 g) catalyst (40–60 mesh) was set at the middle of the reactor and the mixed gas flow (20 vol.% O2/80 vol.% Ar) containing about 1000 ppm n-butylamine was kept at 400 mL/min (gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 24,000 h−1). The combustion temperature was controlled by K-type thermocouples and the concentrations of n-butylamine (inlet and outlet) and CO and CO2 (outlet) was measured by an online gas chromatograph (GC-9890B, Shanghai Linghua Co., China) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and HT-Wax column in 30 m × 0.32 mm (ID) × 0.5 μm. The NO and NO2 at the outlet were measured by an infrared gas analyzer (JNYQ-1-41C, Juneng, China). Stability test was performed at 280 °C and concentrations of reactant and products (NOx) were test on line with gas chromatograph and the infrared analyzer. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural and textural properties of synthesized materials The small-angle XRD patterns of SBA-15-r supports are shown in Fig. 1 A. Three well resolved diffraction peaks centered at around 1.02°, 1.74°, and 2.00° can be respectively assigned to the (100), (110), and (200) reflections of p6mm hexagonal symmetry [14]. The alteration in intensity and position of the diffraction peaks can be observed. The intensity of (100) diffraction peak decreases firstly with the H3PO4 amount increases from 1/3 to 2 (mole ratio), and then increases with the increasing of H3PO4 amount to 3, indicating that the presence of low amount of H3PO4 reduces the pore regularity of the support. Moreover, the (100) peak shifts slightly to higher angles when H3PO4 amount is lower than 2, suggesting that the decrease of d(100) spacing and unit cell parameter (α 0), as displayed in Table S1. However, when H3PO4/HCl equal to 3, the (100) peak shifts to lower angles again, indicating the increase of d(100) and α 0. The alteration of pore regularity and d(100) spacing of various supports can be attributed to the change of pH values and ionic strength in the synthesis system with the addition of H3PO4 [21,28], which influence the rate of evolution of micellar structure, leading to the structural difference in various samples [29]. The wide-angle XRD patterns of Pd supported samples are shown in Fig. 1B. A broad diffraction peak at 2θ ≈ 23° is ascribed to the amorphous silicon in framework of SBA-15-r [15]. Three diffraction peaks centered at 2θ = 40.1°, 47.7°, and 68.1° respectively correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) reflections of metallic Pd (JCPDS 46-1043) as some larger particles is unavoidable formed over the external surface of support although the incipient wetness impregnation we used can introduce most of the palladium particles into SBA-15 channels. No diffraction peak corresponding to palladium oxide can be observed. No diffraction peak corresponding to palladium oxide can be observed. Fig. S1 shows the low-temperature nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of synthesized SBA-15-r supports. The textural parameters obtained from N2 sorption measurement are listed in Table S1. All supports exhibit type IV adsorption isotherms with a H1 hysteresis loop, suggesting that SBA-15-r materials have ordered mesoporous channels and narrow pore size distribution [30]. The specific surface area of supports increases from 319 to 760 m2/g firstly when increase the H3PO4 adding amount from 1/3 to 2, while further increase the H3PO4 amount leads to an obvious reduction of specific surface area. The increases at P/P 0 < 0.1 in the adsorption isotherms are due to the filling of micropores [31]. The samples (except S-3) synthesized with phosphoric acid exhibit more N2 adsorption at P/P 0 < 0.1, indicting the existence of more micropores. The pore size distributions based on BJH and HK methods are presented in Fig. S1B and C, respectively. Fig. S1B reveals that all SBA-15-r supports have a narrow pore size distribution with average pore diameter centered at about 6.7–7.2 nm. Fig. S1C exhibits that all supports possess structural micropores with average pore size lower than 1.0 nm. The average pore size (D P) of SBA-15-r decreases from 8.4 to 6.4 nm with the increasing of H3PO4 adding amount, proving that the presence of H3PO4 vary the structure of materials, as shown in Table S1. It is shown that all Pd/SBA-15-r catalysts exhibit type IV adsorption/desorption isotherms, indicating that the introduction of Pd nanoparticles has insignificant effect on support structure (Fig. 2 A). It is worth noting that the desorption isotherms of all catalysts shift to lower relative pressures, indicating the existence of open and closed/blocked cylindrical mesopores [32]. This is due to that Pd nanoparticles are confined inside the SBA-15 channels or deposit on the mouth of channels to clog supports pores. The average pore diameter of Pd/SBA-15-r catalysts (6.2–7.2 nm) is lower than that of pure SBA-15-r supports (6.4–8.4 nm), suggesting that the Pd nanoparticles are incorporated into pore channels of supports. Interestingly, dual sharp pore size distributions were obtained for Pd/S-5 and the Pd/S-6. The diameter of the smaller pore is slightly less than the pore size of supports which may be due to the Pd loading. There are two possible reasons for formation of the larger pore: (1) the trimethylbenzene (TMB) which is used as the organic solvent during impregnation is a common pore-expanding agent. As such, the TMB could be introduced into the residual hydrophobic groups, and the pore size can be expanded after calcination, in consistent with previous reports [33]; (2) partial structure of SBA-15 may be deteriorated after multiple calcinations, and partial pore size can be expanded after high-temperature treated in some cases [34]. Among all catalysts, the Pd/S-5 possesses the largest specific surface area (602 m2/g) and highest pore volume (0.75 cm3/g). FT-IR spectra of all supports are shown in Fig. 3 . The band observed at around 808 cm−1 can be assigned to the SiOSi symmetric stretching vibrations [35,36]. The strong and wide bands at around 1250–1000 cm−1 can be attributed to the SiOSi asymmetric stretching vibrations [37]. The bands at around 968 cm−1 are attributed to SiOR+ groups [38], and the position and intensity of this band will change due to the existence of heteroatom in the framework of SBA-15 [35,38–40]. In our work, the slight difference around 968 cm−1 among samples demonstrates the presence of phosphorous in the framework via POSi connection, in accordance with the results reported by Colilla and co-workers [21]. 29Si MAS NMR of S-1 and S-5 materials was performed to investigate the effect of H3PO4 on chemical nature of silicon framework, as shown in Fig. 4 . It is shown that the addition of phosphonium ions not change the overall shape of NMR spectrum. The 29Si NMR peaks at around −90, −100, and −110 ppm can be attributed to the Si-(OSi)2(OH)2 units (Q2), Si-(OSi)3(OH) units (Q3), and Si-(OSi)4 units (Q4), respectively [41]. As shown in Fig. 4, 29Si NMR spectra of S-1 displays bands around −95 ppm (Q2), −104 ppm (Q3), and −111 ppm (Q4). However, the corresponding peaks of S-5 are slightly shifted to positive values, that is, −94 ppm (Q2), −103 ppm (Q3), and −110 ppm (Q4), verifying the different silicon chemical environment between S-1 and S-5 due to the incorporation of P into the silicon framework [42]. The NMR curves were deconvoluted and the signal intensity ratio Q4/(Q3+Q2) represent the surface hydrophobicity. The ratios of Q4/(Q3+Q2) in S-1 and S-5 are 3.79 and 3.54, respectively, indicating the incorporation of P can slightly reduce the surface hydrophobicity of SBA-15-r support [43]. The morphology of all SBA-15-r materials was explored through FE-SEM, and the representative patterns are exhibited in Fig. 5 . It is shown that all samples display well-dispersed short rod-like morphologies with an average diameter and length of ca. 0.5 and 1–2 μm, respectively, much shorter than conventional SBA-15 due to the presence of K+ in the synthesis system [19]. The short pore channels of catalysts are beneficial to molecule diffusion and mass transfer in the reaction. The morphology difference of various samples is slight, indicating that the amounts of H3PO4 have negligible impact on the overall morphology of materials. As a consequence, the morphology effect of prepared catalysts on n-butylamine destruction could be excluded and the influence of internal structure on catalytic performance can be studied more accurately. The morphology and pore structure of representative catalysts were further characterized by HR-TEM, as displayed in Fig. 6 . Ordered mesopores arranged in 2D hexagonal p6mm structure with average pore diameter of ca. 6.0–7.5 nm can be observed, in agreement with the results obtained from N2 sorption (Table 1 ). Pd nanoparticles are well-dispersed and confined in the channels as the hydrophobic Pd(acac)2 precursor was infiltrated into the inner pores of SBA-15-r in organic solvent through the incipient wetness impregnation. By this method, the Pd precursor can be confined in carbon due to carbonization of furfuryl alcohol, promoting the formation of highly dispersed Pd nanoparticles and avoiding particle aggregation in the following calcination process [44]. 3.2 Redox property and chemical status of catalysts The reducibility of all prepared catalysts was studied by H2-TPR, as displayed in Fig. 7 . The negative peak below 100 °C appears over all catalysts due to the decomposition of PdHx [37,45,46]. Previous work proposed that the temperature of PdHx decomposition (T PdHx) closely relates to the palladium particle size, that is, the lower the temperature, the smaller the particle size [46]. Fig. 7 reveals that the temperature peaks for PdHx decomposition over Pd/S-4 (69 °C), Pd/S-5 (49 and 78 °C), and Pd/S-6 (48 and 77 °C) are lower than those of Pd/S-1 (78 °C), Pd/S-2 (74 °C), and Pd/S-3 (77 °C), suggesting that Pd particles are better dispersed over Pd/S-4, Pd/S-5, and Pd/S-6 than the other materials, in accordance with the CO pulse chemisorption results (Table 1). Interestingly, two negative peaks can be observed over Pd/S-5 and Pd/S-6, indicating the existence of two kinds of Pd particles with different size, in agreement with the pore size distribution profiles (Fig. 2B). Additionally, no H2 consumption peaks can be observed over all materials. One reason is that no stable PdO exists on the catalyst after H2 reduction, and the other reason is that the highly dispersed PdO which consumes H2 even below 0 °C cannot be detected under our experimental condition [47]. The Pd content and dispersion over all catalysts are listed in Table 1. It can be observed that there is an obvious positive correlation between Pd dispersion and specific surface area and support porosity. For instance, the Pd dispersion of Pd/S-2 and Pd/S-4 is 25.6% and 47.4%, the specific surface area and pore volume of them are 301 m2/g, 0.49 cm3/g and 513 m2/g, 0.65 cm3/g, respectively. Above results indicate that the surface area and porosity of supports play important roles in Pd dispersion, in consistent with previous works [4,48,49]. Fig. S2A presents the Pd 3d XPS spectra of prepared materials. Two peaks with binding energies centered at around 335.6 and 340.8 eV can be observed over all samples, which can be respectively assigned to Pd 3d5/2 and Pd 3d3/2 of metallic Pd [50,51]. The peaks corresponding to PdO cannot be found, proving that just metallic Pd exists over all catalysts, in agreement with the results of XRD (Fig. 1) and H2-TPR (Fig. 7). Fig. S2B shows the O1 s XPS spectra of samples. The peaks around 533.5 and 534.2 eV are attributed to the hydroxyl oxygen or weakly chemisorbed oxygen [50,52]. The similar XPS spectra of these samples verify that the difference of supports has a little influence on metal status and oxygen species. 3.3 Catalytic performance of prepared materials The temperature dependence on the conversion and the reaction rate of n-butylamine as well as the yield of main byproducts during n-butylamine combustion over prepared materials were investigated and depicted in Fig. 8 . Fig. 8A displays the light-off curves of n-butylamine combustion over prepared catalysts, and the temperatures for 50% and 90% conversion of n-butylamine (T 50, T 90) are listed in Table 2 . It can be clearly seen that Pd/S-5 possesses the best activity for n-butylamine combustion among all catalysts. On basis of T 90, the catalytic activity of obtained materials follows the order of Pd/S-5 > Pd/S-6 > Pd/S-4 > Pd/S-2 ≥ Pd/S-1 > Pd/S-3, in agreement with the order of specific surface area and porosity. As is known, the principal difference among the SBA-15-r supports in our work is their surface area and pore volume. As such, we conclude that larger surface area and higher porosity could enhance the dispersion and accessibility of Pd active sites and accelerate the diffusion of n-butylamine molecule and transmission of small molecule products, improving the catalytic activity. Noteworthily, the activity gap among all samples is wider in low temperature and narrower in high temperature regions. We conclude that the molecule velocity is accelerated with the increasing of reaction temperature, causing the activity promotion which relies on the enhance of mass transfer (becomes less remarkable at high temperature). The n-butylamine combustion rate over catalysts were calculated and shown in Fig. 8B. The reaction rates at 220 °C are listed in Table 2, which is in the sequence of Pd/S-5 > Pd/S-6 > Pd/S-4 > Pd/S-2 ≥ Pd/S-3 > Pd/S-1. In the present work, the structure of catalysts is correlated to the activity. Fig. 10A shows a correlation between T 50, T 90 and micropore content, the existence of micropore promotes the activity through the enhancement of mass transfer. Carberry number (Ca) and Weize-Prater criterion (N W-P) are often used to estimate the external diffusion influence and internal diffusion effect, respectively. At the conversion of n-butylamine lower than 20% (160 °C), Ca and N W-P of catalysts were calculated and shown in Table 2. In general, the influence of external diffusion can be neglected when the Ca number is less than 0.05 [53]. The Ca number can be calculated according to the following equations: (a) Carberry number :(1) : (2) C a = r o b s k g , i ⋅ a s ( C i 0 - C i ) (b) Reynolds numbers: (3) R e = ρ g u d μ (c) Schmidt number: (4) S c = μ ρ g D B , i (d) gas-solid diffusion of the catalysts: (5) k g , i = D B , i R S c 1 3 R e J D (e) Colbum factor: (6) J D = 1 θ ( 0.765 R e 0.82 + 0.365 R e 0.386 ) where Ca is the Carberry number, as is the external surface area of the prepared catalysts (m2 m−3), kg,i is the gas-solid diffusion of the catalysts (m s-1), robs is apparent reaction rate (mol m−3 s−1), Ci ° is concentration of specie i before reaction(mol m-3), Ci is the concentration of specie i after reaction (assumed to be equal the concentration at the particle surface) (mol m−3), Re is the Reynolds numbers, Sc is Schmidt number, JD is Colbum factor, ρg is density of gas (kg m−3), u is the liner velocity of the gas in the catalyst bed (m s−1), d is the diameter of the catalyst bed (m), μ is Molecular viscosity (Pa s), θ is porosity of catalyst bed and DB,i is the bulk diffusivity of specie i (m2 s−1). It is observed that the Ca of all catalysts are less than 0.05, indicating that the influence of external diffusion is insignificant. When the N W-P is less than 0.3, the internal diffusion effect can be neglected, moreover, the smaller N W-P means the less diffusion effect [53,54]. From Table 2, we can see that the internal diffusion limitation exist in all catalysts except Pd/S-6. The N W-P can be calculated based on the following formulas: (f) Weisz-Prater criterion: (7) N w-p = r o b s R 2 D e f f , i C i (g) effective diffusivity in the pores of the catalyst: (8) D e f f , i = ε τ D P , i (9) 1 D P , i = 1 D k , i + 1 D B , i (10) D k , i = 1 3 d p 8 R T π M i (11) 1 D B , i = 1 1 − y i ∑ j = 2 n y i D i , j (12) D i , j = 0.001 T 1.5 P Σ V i 1 3 + Σ V j 1 3 2 1 M i + 1 M j 1 2 where R is the radius of the catalyst pellet (m), Deff,i is the effective diffusivity in the pores of the catalyst (m2 s−1) Dp,i is the diffusion coefficient in the pores (m2 s−1), Dk,i is the Kundsen diffusion coefficient (m2 s−1), dp is the pore diameter of the catalyst, yi is mole percent content of diffusing specie i (dimensionless), Mi is the molecular weight of the specie i (kg mol−1), ∑Vi is molecular diffusion volume (cm3 mol−1), P is reaction pressure (Pa), T is temperature of catalyst bed (K), ε is the porosity of catalyst (dimensionless) and τ is tortuosity factor (dimensionless). There is a clear connection between N W-P and porosity of catalysts. For instance, the total pore volume of Pd/S-5 and Pd/S-3 are 0.75 and 0.44 cm3/g, and the N W-P of them are 0.7573 and 0.4196, respectively, proving that Pd/S-5 has less internal diffusion limitation. In brief, based on N W-P, the higher porosity of catalyst benefit the catalytic activity by enhancing the mass transfer. The yield of NOx is a vital indicator to evaluate the performance of a catalyst for NVOCs combustion. The NO and NO2 yields during n-butylamine combustion are depicted in Fig. 8C and D. Both NO and NO2 yields increase slowly with the increasing of reaction temperature. The NOx yields of all catalysts at T 90 are listed in Table 2. It can be found that the NOx yields of Pd/S-1 (2.0%), Pd/S-2 (2.1%), and Pd/S-3 (1.3%) are higher than those of Pd/S-4 (0.9%), Pd/S-5(0.8%), and Pd/S-6 (0.8%). We propose that the presence of large amounts of micropores in mesopore channel walls of prepared catalysts play important roles in NOx formation control. The correlation between NOx yield at T 50, T 90 and micropore content of catalyst are depicted in Fig. 10B. The more micropore content indeed corresponds to the lower NOx yield, the reason for this may be relative to the path of NOx produced. The amounts of NOx produced over catalyst are shown in Fig. 9 . The stability and NOx yield of Pd/S-5 who has better catalytic activity than other materials were further investigated at 280 °C for 20 h. As shown in Fig. 11 , no noticeable fluctuation of catalytic activity and NOx yield (6.0%) can be observed during the whole stability test. Above results indicate that the Pd/S-5 possesses good catalytic activity, superior stability, and low NOx yield, endowing it a promising and potential catalyst for n-butylamine catalytic destruction. 3.4 N-butylamine destruction route The possible catalytic combustion pathway over Pd/S-5 was further investigated through in situ DRIFTS in order to clarify the role of micropores in n-butylamine combustion, and the newly generated surface species during the oxidation of n-butylamine at different temperature points were detected, as shown in Fig. 12 . There are three intense bands which can be always observed in the region of 3000–2800 cm−1 correspond to the vibration of CH (ν(CH)) [55]. The bands at 3375, 3316, and 1590 cm−1 can be observed at 120–160 °C, which can be attributed to the absorbed NHx species [56]. The bands at 3375 and 3316 cm−1 correspond to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of NH (νasym(NH) and νsym(NH)), respectively. The band at 1590 cm−1 can be assigned to the NH deformation vibration (δ(NH)) [57]. Along with the temperature increases up to 180 °C, the ν(NH) and δ(NH) gradually diminish and vanish finally. At the same time, the new band at 1667 cm−1 assigned to amide appeared [56]. The bands corresponding to amide disappeared when the reaction temperature reaches 220 °C, while another band at 1700 cm−1, being assigned to acids, was generated [57]. The band at 2363 cm−1 corresponds to CO2, which always presents in high temperature region may be derived from byproducts [55]. Based on the above results, the overall mechanism for n-butylamine destruction can be summarized in the following substeps, namely, n-butylamine is firstly oxidized to amide, and then the amide reacts with H2O to form NH3 and acids accompanied by C–N bond cleavage. Finally, the acids is oxidized by the oxygen absorbed at active site to form CO2 and H2O. The NHx is oxidized by the oxygen to form NOx. Due to the reaction temperature is rather low, it is the only source of NOx during n-butylamine combustion. The surface chemical state of palladium sites on the fresh and used Pd/S-5 materials were investigated, as shown in Fig. S3. Two peaks with binding energies at around 335.8 and 341.0 eV are attributed to the Pd° 3d5/2 and Pd° 3d3/2, respectively. The others at around 337.6 and 342.3 eV are belong to the Pd2+ 3d5/2 and Pd2+ 3d3/2, respectively [50]. From XPS results, it can be concluded that no PdO exists on the fresh Pd/S-5, and the palladium species has been totally reduced to metallic state after H2 treatment. However, the metallic palladium in the used Pd/S-5 is partially oxidized into PdO during n-butylamine oxidation, which indicates that the palladium site participates in the reaction (not just a adsorption site). As a consequence, a two-step redox model can be suggested [51,58,59], which is generally accepted in VOC catalytic oxidation over Pd-supported catalysts [5]. That is, partial metallic palladium (Pd°) is oxidized into Pd2+O2− when O2 is present, and the Pd2+O2− is reduced by organics (HC) subsequently. Then, the catalyst redox center (Pd°) is oxidized to recover Pd2+O2−. The proposed n-butylamine catalytic destruction mechanism was illustrated in Scheme 1 and summarized as follows: O 2 +Cat • → Cat-O RN H 2 +Cat-O → R'-CON H 2 + Cat • R'-CON H 2 + H 2 O → N H 3 +R'-COOH R'-COOH+Cat-O → CO+C O 2 + Cat • N H 3 +Cat-O → N O x + H 2 O+Cat • where R and R' are n-butyl and n-propyl. Additionally, the NH deformation vibration which NH deformation vibration which disappeared at 160 °C and appeared again at 220 °C, and the stretching vibration of NH2 never appeared again. This phenomenon may be due to the alkyl groups exchange reaction of primary amines over palladium, and the secondary amines produced [60,61]. Since the n-butylamine catalytic oxidation reacted between gas and solid phase, and the concentration of n-butylamine is low in our work, so the oxidation of amine to amide is the main reaction form. The alkyl groups exchange reaction is not a major pathway in oxidation process, as a possible side-reaction. Based on the result of in situ DRIFTs, NOx was produced due to the oxidation of NH3 in channles of catalysts. If NHx can leave the catalyst quickly, it has little chance to contact with active sites to form NOx. Herein, the micropore is helpful to improve the mass transfer rate especially for product with small molecular dynamic diameter, inhibiting the formation of NOx. Secondly, higher porosity is beneficial to improve the catalytic efficiency of catalyst and reduce n-butylamine activation temperature, suppressing the generation of NOx which greatly depends on the reaction temperature [4]. Thus, we concluded that the more micropores is helpful to control the harmful byproducts. The Scheme 2 is straightforward and vivid to explain it. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of rod-like supports SBA-15 with different specific surface area and pore volume was synthesized by adding K+ and different amount of H3PO4 into the synthetic system. The palladium active phase was led into SBA-15 channels by a novel incipient wetness impregnation method. The catalytic results for n-butylamine combustion show that Pd/S-5 has better catalytic activity than others. High porosity of materials can improve the diffusion of reactants and products, and the high surface area benefit the dispersion of metal particle. In addition, we find that the catalyst with high porosity shows advantage in controlling NOx production. Based on our analysis, one reason for this is that the high porosity can decrease the removal temperature then reduce the NOx production. The other reason for this is that the existence of micropore get NHx off catalysts timely avoiding further oxidation at active site to form NOx. Generally, it is concluded that porosity and surface area of catalyst make notable effects on the activity and selectivity of n-butylamine combustion. It is predictable that micro-mesoporous materials will attract more attentions and play a significant role in NVOCs, catalytic combustion. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic destruction of nitrogen-containing volatile organic compounds (NVOCs) is rarely reported although they can make great harm to the environment and public health. In the present work, a series of short rod-like micro-mesoporous composite SBA-15 materials (SBA-15-r) with developed porosity and enhanced mass transfer performance were rationally designed and synthesized, and highly dispersed and thermally stable Pd nanoparticles were successfully introduced into the mesopore channels of SBA-15-r via an extraordinary incipient wetness impregnation with the assistance of furfuryl alcohol and trimethylbenzene. The correlation between catalyst property and catalytic performance in n-butylamine destruction was elucidated. 29Si MAS NMR and FT-IR results show that phosphorus is incorporated into the skeleton of SBA-15-r through a POSi connection, altering the structural property of support. All Pd/SBA-15-r materials are highly active and stable catalysts with n-butylamine totally converted at 280 °C. Amongst, Pd/S-5 possesses the best n-butylamine oxidation activity and lowest NOx formation rate ascribable to the largest surface area and highest porosity which can promote the dispersion of Pd active sites and accelerate the oxidation process and product diffusion, inhibiting the formation of reaction byproducts. Moreover, the structural micropores over Pd/SBA-15-r catalysts play an important positive role in NOx formation control. The n-butylamine destruction mechanism were further discussed according to the results of gas chromatography and in situ DRIFTS. We believe that the present work provides new insights into the design and application of high-efficient catalysts based on hierarchical materials in NVOC elimination.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active SBA-15-confined Pd catalyst with short rod-like micro-mesoporous hybrid nanostructure for n-butylamine low-temperature destruction
